proof-by-refutation-2 (math concept)

See also

python declaration class | python inclusion class | python sample

Definition

proof-by-refutation-2 is the inference-rule:

\[\left( \boldsymbol{\mathcal{H}} assume \not \mathbf{P}, Inc\left(\mathcal{H}\right) \right) \vdash \mathbf{P}\]

Where:

  • \(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{H}}\) is an hypothesis

  • \(\boldsymbol{P}\) is formula

In plain language, if we pose the hypothesis that a proposition \(\boldsymbol{P}\) is not true, and if we refute that hypothesis by proving \(\boldsymbol{P}\), the inconsistency of that hypothesis follows from this contradiction, and \(\boldsymbol{P}\) follows from that inconsistency.
